title: Erigon 2 commit cycle is slower than Erigon 1.
body:
#### System information

Erigon version: v2022.04.04 (devel)
Commit hash : 47f492663ee48fd15aa5bc52ff82211b658e44be
Machine specs: 64 GB ram, AMD 3900x, 4TB Nvme gen4 ssd
OS & Version: Linux Debian

#### Expected behavior
Before updating and resyncing erigon 2, blocks used to import fast and "Commit cycle" average was 30 ms, and up to 100-150 at worst cases. 

#### Actual behavior
After updating some commits are fast (20-30 ms) and some really slow (1+ up to 6 secs)
Behavior is the same while running RPC daemon in the same or different process.
The node is warmed-up

Erigon log:

Thank you. 
I think best solution for this problem (on only in Erigon2 context, but in-general): `--syncmode=snap`

For more context you can add:
- cli flags of erigon
- `make db-tools` then `./build/bin/mdbx_stat -ef <yrou_datadir>/chaindata`

Thanks a lot!

The alpha node is freshly synced with defalut params, so it synced normally with `--syncmode=snap`
Also when starting logs look normal
`Effective                                prune_flags="--prune=" snapshot_flags="--syncmode=snap"`
Does explicitly adding `--syncmode=snap` change anything? Isn't snap only for the initial sync?
I added the flag anyways but commit times look the same.

cli flags:
`--syncmode=snap --datadir /erigon --txpool.disable --torrent.download.rate=60mb --torrent.upload.rate=2mb --maxpeers 15 --ethash.dagdir /erigon/erigon-ethash --port 30305 --trustedpeers=enode://<my geth node running in the same machine>`

mdbx_stat 1hr after restarting the node :

**UPDATE:**
Interestingly after leaving the node running for a few hours, the "slow" commit cycles are now a lot better ranging from 250-500 ms. Better but still way higher of what they used to be. Note I used to run erigon1 with the exact same setup / startup args.

current mdbx_stat:

Yes. It must get even better after 1 more day. 
Thanks. We will improve it step by step.

Just an update here: after running 2 days, commit times look to be back to 700ms - 1 sec, and consistently falling 2-3 secs behind geth. I also increased max peers to 30, but that doesn't look to have any positive effect.

@AskAlexSharov this issue persists. In the original issue (was still devel alpha), after letting the node run for 1-2 days and updating it I was able to get commit cycle to average at 30-80ms which was really nice, and was consistent while updating to latest devel regularly.

After a recent fresh sync on e0323e7434eb148ce3bd3db59173f3d3bfa4d9c4 and about 1-1.5 day of letting it run 4-7 seconds commit times are back.

@geomad can you try branch `mdbx_aug_dbg`?  let Erigon run for couple hours and show:
- before and after run: `mdbx_stat -ef <your_datadir>/chaindata | grep GC`
- new `Commit cycle` from logs
if you see no change, then do same for branch `mdbx_aug_dbg_64`

> @geomad can you try branch `mdbx_aug_dbg`? let Erigon run for couple hours and show:
> 
> * before and after run: `mdbx_stat -ef <your_datadir>/chaindata | grep GC`
> * new `Commit cycle` from logs
>   if you see no change, then do same for branch `mdbx_aug_dbg_64`

hi, fix for "slow commit cycle" was merged and released: https://github.com/ledgerwatch/erigon/pull/4750

> hi, fix for "slow commit cycle" was merged and released: #4750

Thanks! I have already updated, but the `--snap.stop` that fixed it for me the last time is still there. Will test without it whenever I have time and report if anything is wrong!
Can you briefly explain why this happen? Which exact commit solve this? Trying to figure out the reason but seems there are many things changed in #4750

Commit: https://gitflic.ru/project/erthink/libmdbx/commit/2cfcfcf91ce749c2f517766580f9838773d34464
Because mdbx didn’t handle well big FreeList. To update big freelist it was need search for big sequential pages range in big FreeList. 

Now it can store freelist in many small records. Update of such records is way cheaper.
LMDB had same problem - we did patch it also.
Thank you! Tested and works well now.
